content.Topic: Introductory course in computer vision. Topics include image formation and optics, image sensing, binary images, image processing and filtering, edge extraction and boundary detection, region growing and segmentation, pattern classification methods, brightness and reflectance, shape from shading and photometric stereo, texture, binocular stereo, optical flow and motion, 2D and 3D object representation, object recognition, vision systems and applications.
content.Exam Dates: Midterm Exam (In-Person): October 17, 10:10AM - 11:25AM (1 hour, 15 mins), Final Exam (In-Person): December 14, 10:00 AM - 1:00 PM (3 Hours)
content.Lecture Schedule: Lecutures available on Youtube for your own pace.

content.style: Lecture-based format using handout pdf slides
prerequisites: No previous knowledge of Computer Vision is needed.

content.liked: I like this course a lot

content.Topic: This course covers the basics of the design and analysis of algorithms. We will study general algorithmic techniques such as divide and conquer, greedy algorithms and dynamic programming. We will also discuss some important graph algorithms as well as NP-completeness and techniques for dealing with it. In the process of doing so, we will investigate several important algorithms such as sorting, shortest paths and longest common substrings.
content.Grading: 6 Homeworks (35%), Midterm (25%): Oct 23th in-class, Final (40%): finals week
content.Lecture Schedule: Week 1: Introduction, Strassen's Matrix Multiplication. Week 2: Recurrences, Heapsort, Loop invariants. Week 3: Lower bounds for sorting, Counting Sort, Radix Sort. Week 4: Indicator Random Variables. Week 5: Dynamic Programming. Week 6: Greedy Algorithms. Week 7: Amortized Analysis. Week 8: Midterm. Week 9: Strongly Connected Components, Minimum Spanning Trees, Disjoint Sets. Week 10: All pairs shortest paths. Week 11: NP-completeness. Week 12: Approximation Algorithms.

content.style: Lecture-based format using handout pdf slides

content.liked: I like this course a lot
